responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Potentially sensitive information exposed in install script
    analysis: |
      The install script `tests/bin/install-wp-tests.sh` directly includes database credentials passed as command line arguments into a configuration file. While this script appears to be used only for setting up tests, if the script or the generated configuration file is included in a public repository, it could expose the database name, user, and password.

      To investigate further, determine how this install script is used and if it handles production database credentials. Also check if the script or wp-tests-config.php file it generates is ever included in a public repo.
    cwe: CWE-522
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - tests/bin/install-wp-tests.sh
    classification: slightly promising
  
  - headline: Improper neutralization of special elements in output
    analysis: |
      The JavaScript code in `assets/text-hover.js` takes the `title` attribute of `abbr` elements and inserts it into a tooltip without any apparent escaping or sanitization. If the title can contain HTML from an untrusted source, this could allow cross-site scripting (XSS).

      To develop a proof-of-concept, identify where the `title` attribute of the matched `abbr` elements comes from. If it can contain user input, try including HTML and JavaScript in the title to see if it is executed when hovering.
    cwe: CWE-79
    function_names: []
    filenames: 
      - assets/text-hover.js
    classification: very promising
```

leads.headline: Potentially sensitive information exposed in install script
leads.analysis:
The install script tests/bin/install-wp-tests.sh directly includes database credentials passed as command line arguments into a configuration file. While this script appears to be used only for setting up tests, if the script or the generated configuration file is included in a public repository, it could expose the database name, user, and password.

To investigate further, determine how this install script is used and if it handles production database credentials. Also check if the script or wp-tests-config.php file it generates is ever included in a public repo.

leads.headline: Improper neutralization of special elements in output
leads.analysis:
The JavaScript code in assets/text-hover.js takes the title attribute of abbr elements and inserts it into a tooltip without any apparent escaping or sanitization. If the title can contain HTML from an untrusted source, this could allow cross-site scripting (XSS).

To develop a proof-of-concept, identify where the title attribute of the matched abbr elements comes from. If it can contain user input, try including HTML and JavaScript in the title to see if it is executed when hovering.
